candidates.title: Merge crypto from next

labels.name: cryptography
labels.description: An issue involving cryptography/a cryptographic library

candidates.body:
This does not merge the one-round eVRF-premised DKG from the `next` branch. It checks out the entire folder, removes the eVRF-premised DKG, and then proceeds to reorganize `dkg` into a smashed set of crates. This lets:
1) The changes from `next` to the `ThresholdKeys` struct to be applied
2) Us merge in the one-round eVRF-premised DKG. We only had the next branch as `dkg` is covered by a bug bounty, and the eVRF-premised DKG was written into `dkg`, so merging it would in-scope it under the bug bounty. With this new modular approach to `dkg` (which is optimal regardless as we now have multiple algorithms), we now have that option and can continue further merging `next`.
3) `monero-oxide` update to the new version of `dkg`.
4) The `next` branch replace its inlined `monero-serai` with `monero-oxide`.

candidates.title: Monero Audit

labels.name: monero
labels.description: An issue with the Monero library/integration

candidates.body:
Responds to the findings from Cypher Stack's audit, as applicable. The notes on the Monero protocol themselves have been ignored, though carefully considered re: documentation. Additionally, the transcripting re: the multisig code has been left as-is. While the audit notes it isn't to preference, and can be hard to follow, the audit confirms its validity. In my opinion, it'd be worse to change harder-to-read, audited-as-correct code than have easy-to-read, unaudited code.

The move away from `unwrap`, overall, has produced better code and is pleasant.

candidates.title: add Serai JSON-RPC methods
candidates.body: addresses the issue https://github.com/serai-dex/serai/issues/625

candidates.title: Constant-time divisors

labels.name: cryptography
labels.description: An issue involving cryptography/a cryptographic library

candidates.body: This is 9.6x slower yet ensures timing analysis of the divisor calculation doesn't leak any information about the secret key.

candidates.title: add validator sets pallet tests
candidates.body: These tests make the ones in `substrate/client/tests/validator_sets.rs` absolute. They would now only be valuable as testing the connection to pallet functions(txs) and also everything is still running as expected under a proper runtime and block production but not valuable as a test to actual pallet functionality. So there is a question to remove or still keep them. If we decide to keep them a better place might under `tests/` as an e2e tests.

candidates.title: Smash Processor
candidates.body:
This smashes the processor into several crates. It resolves several issues, as documented in #569. It also finishes the Ethereum processor, properly supporting tokens and fees for relayers.

Almost completely untested. The existing tests have yet to be moved/adjusted, the coordinator isn't operable, and the e2e tests definitely won't work. I plan to step through the coordinator next before rebuilding the e2e stack.

candidates.title: move economic security into it's own pallet
One Round DKG
candidates.body:
Implement https://github.com/serai-dex/serai/issues/576.

Resolves lingering security issues with the DKG re-attempt protocol by removing the DKG re-attempt protocol, and moving to a DKG where there are no excluded parties upon completion (nor parties potentially with invalid shares).

This can't be merged. It adds ~10k lines of unaudited cryptography which is expected to be audited over the next 2-3 months. If it was merged now, it'd become in-scope automatically under our bug bounty program, and I'm unwilling to place such a bounty on such a degree of unaudited code. I do want this to the basis for further processor/coordinator clean ups though.

candidates.title: Rust 1.80
candidates.body: Preserves the fn accessors within the Monero crates so that we can use statics in some cfgs yet not all (in order to provide support for more low-memory devices) with the exception of `H` (which truly should be cached).

candidates.title: Rename the coins folder to networks
candidates.body:
Ethereum isn't a coin. It's a network.

Resolves #357.

labels.name: monero
labels.description: An issue with the Monero library/integration

candidates.body:
This still needs:

1) More tests in general
2) More documentation improvements from #568
3) Potentially uplifting the FCMP++ BP to replace the BP impl present here
4) Resolution of TODOs

Yet it is time to start running the CI again.

candidates.title: Use the serai_abi::Call in the actual Transaction type
candidates.body:
We prior required they had the same encoding, yet this ensures they do by making them one and the same. This does require an large, ugly, From/TryInto block which is deemed preferable for moving this more and more into syntax (from semantics).

Further improvements (notably re: Extra) is possible, and this already lets us strip some members from the Call enum.

candidates.title: Check if wasm was built by container exit code and state instead of local mountpoint
Ethereum Integration

labels.name: ethereum
labels.description: An issue with the Ethereum integration

candidates.body:
This is not ready for production. It does a lot of the leg work on the actual integration, and is far along enough I'd like to start running the CI on it.

In general, what needs to be done:
1) Update the documentation
2) Implement fee handling
3) Have user specification of the gas limit (instead of a constant)
4) Have an additional service to publish TXs through
5) Build a better pattern for event retrieval
6) Move ScannerEvent::Completed from a tuple to a struct
7) Re-define `key_for_any_change` to a stricter definition, as currently expected
8) Make a proper trait for Eventuality Completions
9) Handle top-level transfers in the processor

What has been done:
1) Moved to alloy (#331), including developing a new transport around our own simple-request
2) Adds deterministic deployment of the Router, offering efficient location without DoS risks
3) Adds a Sandbox to make aggregated calls with
4) Fleshes out the Router
5) Makes the Scheduler generic to the processor (starting the road on #289)
6) Replaces transaction signing with eventuality completion, a higher layer of abstraction
7) Moves creation of refund and forwarding plans into the scheduler

candidates.title: Remove subxt
candidates.body:
Removes ~20 crates from our Cargo.lock.

Removes downloading the metadata and enables removing the getMetadata RPC route (relevant to #379).

Moves forward #337.

Done now due to distinctions in the subxt 0.32 API surface which make it justifiable to not update.

candidates.title: Ensure economic security on validator sets
Resolve #360
candidates.body: Uses session instead of key and performs other misc optimizations.

candidates.title: Use parity-db in current Dockerfiles
candidates.body: The motivation for redb was to remove the multiple rocksdb compile times from CI.

candidates.title: Move message-queue to a fully binary representation
candidates.body: Additionally adds a timeout to the message queue test.

candidates.title: Replace bincode with borsh
candidates.body:
Replaces a non-canonical encoding with a canonical encoding which additionally may be faster slightly faster, yet at least is effectively the same.

Also fixes multiple issues such as:
- Usage of bincode (a non-canonical format) in transcripts
- `create_db!` not binding to type in `set`, correction of which raised further errors

And causes improvements such as:
- No-longer JSON encoding processor messages in a nested byte buffer. A further PR should move message-queue off HTTP JSON-RPC to raw sockets entirely.
- Not needing a Vec<u8> for some processor messages, as we can now use [u8; 64]
- 10-20% reduced disk usage, per generic benchmark results present in https://github.com/djkoloski/rust_serialization_benchmark.

While this was initially meant to be an experiment like the QUIC branch, the observed issues and included fixes necessitate merging of this branch or porting it to a new PR and merging that.

candidates.title: Non-intrusive cargo update
candidates.body: Done on a branch just to be sure this doesn't bork anything due to the k256 update (which changed behavior re: ECDSA key recovery).
